page.title: 02HISTORY OF MORTEHOE
page.content: The name Mortehoe possibly comes from a Germanic word meaning short or stumpy, and probably refers to Morte Point in comparison with Baggy point south of Woolacombe. There is evidence that the area was settled in Stone Age times, and the Domesday Book mentions Morthou as a small manor with a home farm, two smallholders and one serf, the estate of Ralf de Limesi, William's nephew. In the twelfth century, it is believed, Henry II banished one of the Knights who murdered Thomas Becket, de Tracy, to Mortehoe, where his family held land. There is a family tomb in the church, though the guilty Knight went off to do penance in the Holy Land.
